initiatives.title: Support
initiatives.description: Learn more about the many free services you can access as a prostate cancer patient or their loved one—anywhere in Canada.

initiatives.title: Awareness
initiatives.description: All you need to know about prostate cancer—from who needs to get checked to living well with cancer  and beyond.

initiatives.title: Research
initiatives.description: We've had the pleasure of funding incredible research scientists and programs over the years.

accordion.title: What should I expect from a support group?
accordion.content:
You can expect to have the opportunity to ask questions and tell us how it's been for you, or what concerns you. Or don't - it's OK to be a wallflower.

We understand that talking about your (or your partner's) prostate problems can be awkward, uncomfortable or even intimidating. Rest assured, you're among friends: most of us have been there, done that. And so have our spouses/partners (who are most welcome).

In many support groups, you may hear subjects discussed that may not be suitable for “the church picnic” - such as: erections, sex, incontinence, penis, diapers, sex-toys, leaking.

But you'll also hear words like: Gleason, PSA, prostatectomy, brachytherapy, uro-dynamics, Kegels, oncology, radiation, ADT, catheters, hormone therapy, side-effects, erectile dysfunction, and depression.

accordion.title: Do groups ever offer webinars or expert presentations?
accordion.content:
Many meetings include presentations by specialists and experts in prostate cancer followed by an opportunity for Q&A and a discussion period. Presentations are on a range of topics including: incontinence, sexuality, symptom management, living well with prostate cancer, and emerging research and treatment options.

Expert presentations are advertised on our support group calendar.

accordion.title: What else should I know?
accordion.content: Meetings are free and everyone is welcome. If you know of someone newly diagnosed, please invite them to come along or join you online.

accordion.title: I’m an advanced patient. Which group should I attend?
accordion.content:
Patients are considered advanced when their prostate cancer has:

  • spread (metastatic)
  • been labeled castrate-resistant (no longer responds to first-line ADT)
  • been diagnosed as high-risk or complex

Our advanced prostate cancer support group meets online the second Wednesday of each month at 4 pm Pacific (7 pm Eastern). Find more information and tailored advanced support at https://advancedprostatecancer.ca

You may also attend the local Warriors groups in Calgary and Toronto. Calgary’s Warriors group meets in-person on the second Tuesday of each month, while the Toronto Warriors group meets every other month on the last Tuesday at 7 pm Eastern. Join a meeting via the calendar.

accordion.title: I’m newly diagnosed and have low-risk prostate cancer. Which group should I attend?
accordion.content:
The Active Surveillance support group meets the second Thursday of each month at 4:30 pm Pacific (7:30 pm Eastern).

Active surveillance is a method of closely monitoring low-risk prostate cancer (usually defined as Gleason 6-7 or lower) with your healthcare provider(s), effectively allowing you to avoid invasive treatments, and their side effects, indefinitely.
Join the support group to learn more about this method.

accordion.title: I’m the partner of a prostate cancer patient. Which group should I attend?
accordion.content:
If you’re looking for information for your partner and want to attend a group with him, most support groups are happy to welcome you to their meetings.

If you’re looking for confidential support and wish to attend a partners-only meeting, you may be interested in our Partners in Prostate group. Find out more or ask questions on the forum at partnersinprostate.ca.

accordion.title: I’m gay. Which group should I attend?
accordion.content: We are currently in the process of creating a support group for gay, bi, and trans prostate cancer patients. To be put on the mailing list for this group to ensure that you’re notified about its first meeting or to request one-on-one support, please contact Richelle at richelle@prostatecancerbc.ca

checkbox.main: MRI Targeted Focal Laser Thermal Therapy of Prostate Cancer
Acupuncture to treat incontinence, erectile dysfunction, and/or ADT induced hot flashes
Artificial urinary sphincter or sling implant
Treatments to manage lower limb lymphedema post-prostatectomy
Treatments for post-prostatectomy sepsis, blood clots, wound infections, cardiovascular complications
Treatments to manage urethral blockage post-prostatectomy
Dietary changes to manage radiation therapy-related bowel symptoms

Treatments to manage side-effects from brachytherapy (Low Density Radiation or High-Density Radiation), external beam radiation therapy, image-guided intensity-modulated radiation therapy, and stereotactic body radiotherapy

content.title: Accommodations during treatment
items: Canadian Cancer Society’s lodges offer an affordable place to stay for people with cancer and their caregivers. They are located near cancer treatment centres and major hospitals. Each lodge offers a variety of amenities to make you feel at home. Learn more here.

content.title: Flights and accommodations for patients in rural areas
items: Hope Air is a charity that provides free flights and accommodations for Canadians in financial need who must reach medical care far from home. Without it, patients would drive for hours, take on unmanageable debt or cancel medical appointments. Learn more here.
Canadian Cancer Society will help you find transportation to your cancer appointments. Learn more here.

content.title: Federal benefits and tax credits
items: Disability tax credit program: While a cancer diagnosis itself is not enough to qualify, you may qualify for the credit if your cancer is significantly impacting your life in other ways. Learn more about the credit here.
Medical expenses: You may be eligible to claim some of your medical expenses on your taxes. For more information on valid claims, click here.
EI sickness benefits: Employment Insurance (EI) sickness benefits can provide you with up to 15 weeks of financial assistance if you can't work for medical reasons. Learn more here.
Your province or territory may have additional support.
